content: I'm looking to form a research network, called something like PhACT (Philosophically-Applied Category Theory), aimed at encouraging dialogue between the ACT and philosophical communities. So, for instance, where there is plenty of ACT work looking to capture causal relations in causal network, there is also decades of work in philosophy on causality, e.g., discussion on different conceptions in Regularity theory, Probabilistic theory, Counterfactual theory, Interventionist theory, Process theory,... The idea then is for some mutually beneficial exchange, where philosophy gains by taking on a powerful formalism. Anyone interested in such a network?

It's an interesting idea. Since you and I are both on the n-Cafe and we're both interested in ACT and philosophy it would theoretically make sense for us to work on this. However, since retirement I've been trying to hole up and finish half-finished projects. I try to be on 'steering boards' where I give occasional advice and don't do any actual work... but sometimes this backfires, as you can see on thread about Compositionality, where I've gotten pulled in to help the journal: some actual work.

It would be great if there were some younger, more ambitious ACTists who wanted to organize interactions with philosophers. It feels like there should be some! But I won't name names here, for fear of putting them on the spot.
Do you have ideas for what the research network might do, concretely?
Apply for grants? Hold workshops? Talk online? Talk about what to do?
Some concrete suggestions might get some people energized.

Hmm honestly, I'm super motivated by this project so I'm a young person who is ready to help but I know nothing about managing something like this. But I'm willing to learn and have already dreamt of something like this recently. We could do an online seminar with alternate talks by mathematicians and philosophers and then maybe it will lead to new philosophico-mathematical works!
Each time I learn something from a friend who knows more than me about philosophy, I'm so excited and I want to know more about philosophy and how it can help me to understand math!

I'll be looking to apply for some money from my side for networks and research time. Access to non-Humanities funding would certainly be welcome.

I had a really interesting chat with Evan Patterson yesterday. Plenty of overlap there. I really don't think parts of the shared activity need to look ever so different from just doing ACT.

One dimension that certainly interests me is a tension between philosophers as to whether scientific theories and scientific inference should be seen as neat or messy. More attention these days is paid to the messy "middle-range theory", e.g., epidemiology, ecology. Here there's a robust tangle of practices (for the messy tangle, see p. 313 of Nancy Cartwright's ' Middle-range theory: Without it what could anyone do?' https://ojs.ehu.eus/index.php/THEORIA/article/download/21479/19859).

The compositionality inherent in the ACT approaches to networks might provide just the right tools.

You might try talking a bit more to Brendan Fong. He tends to be full of good ideas.

For example, did you know Topos is planning to hire an ethicist?

An interesting thing about epidemiology is that they make a lot of models that are only supposed to be good enough to provide useful guidance to governments over the next few weeks; they fully accept that such models need to be tinkered with and updated constantly, so it's utterly different than, say, physics.

An interesting pointer is this interview with Tim Berners-Lee on the subject of the Web as philosophical Engineering. If you take it, as I do that the web should have a CT model, you'd end up with a an applied philosophy of the Web using CT.
https://www.dailymotion.com/video/xfisjf

For example, did you know Topos is planning to hire an ethicist?

By the way, @David Corfield - maybe you've already noticed, but the most violent arguments here on Zulip involve the ethics of applied category theory. So while ACT can probably help philosophy in various ways, perhaps the main way ACT needs help from philosophy involves ethics. (Or perhaps we're doomed to settle ethical questions by mud-wrestling, and wise philosophers will avoid the mud-pit.)
Hi! As you might guess, since I'm a philosopher already engaged in category-theory-flavored projects, I'd be very interested in such a network!
I imagine that most philosophers who know some CT care more for other branches of philosophy and want to use it as a tool in their work.

If one could get counterfactuals into CT then one could use David Lewis' application of counterfactuals to Deontic logic as he sketches in chapter 5 of Counterfactuals. (Lewis is the most widely cited analytic philosophers along with Kripke see this analysis). @Kohei Kishida 's Phd thesis Generalized Topological Semantics for First-Order Modal Logic, reviewed by Steve Awodey, compared Lewis' and Kripke's cross world identity. But it did not show how the distance relation between worlds would work in Category Theory. Perhaps if we knew that we'd see a lot better.

Extract from chapter 5 of Counterfactuals

Just a bit more to give a taste on where that goes:
p97 of Counterfactuals, 5.1 Conditional Obligation

I had some ideas on counterfactuals in my modal HoTT book in terms of stripping back a type-theoretic context. Worlds as developed contexts are closer to the extent that they match. Something like how the unfolding of p-adic numbers indicate their distance at the place they diverge.

John Baez said:

An interesting thing about epidemiology is that they make a lot of models that are only supposed to be good enough to provide useful guidance to governments over the next few weeks; they fully accept that such models need to be tinkered with and updated constantly, so it's utterly different than, say, physics.

This sort of thing interests me - the stability of the model as people tinker with the parts. Showing my ignorance here, is anyone doing ACT work on networks where you can see how coherence emerges from the constraints that parts impose on each other. The kind of thing which it looks like this forthcoming book will be about - Alicia Juarrero, Context Changes Everything: How Constraints Create Coherence?

Added: Evidently I need to catch up with the CASCADE papers: https://johncarlosbaez.wordpress.com/2021/06/25/complex-adaptive-system-design-part-10/

An update on the CASCADE stuff: Joe Moeller and I quit that project, and as best as I know the ideas that excited me the most, like building models from abstract to concrete by climbing up a ladder of forgetful functors, were never implemented. There is now another team working with DARPA on operadic system design, at a company called Two Six Technologies.

I don't know what they're doing. But many of the ideas that excited me the most about this project got a lot better when a bunch of us:

  1. introduced decorated and structured cospans,
  2. introduced operads for composing these,
  3. wrote software to do all this stuff in code: in AlgebraicJulia you can actually refer explicitly to category-theoretic concepts like categories, functors etc.,
  4. used this code to design two systems for composing epidemiological models,
  5. created a graphical user interface that lets you do this on a web browser, and
  6. began implementing, in code, the idea of building models from abstract to concrete by climbing up a ladder of abstractions.

For a general overview of this work see

  • Azimuth Project News.

and for details read

  • John Baez, Xiaoyan Li, Sophie Libkind, Nathaniel D. Osgood and Eric Redekopp, A categorical framework for modeling with stock and flow diagrams.
I'm very excited about this stuff, but I haven't been talking about it on the n-Cafe... for no particularly good reason.
